Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: BISON: Bio-Inspired Solutions for RobustWireless Sensor Networking

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through billions of years 'computation' using 'survival of the fittest' algorithm, biological systems have naturally become robust and self-adaptive to environmental changes, such as perturbations and adverse situations. Inspired by this phenomenon, this ambitious EAGER project, called BISON, will aim to design robust wireless sensor networks (WSNs), by leveraging optimal results from nature's computation. Functional robustness of living organisms is often attributed to the optimized topological structures of gene regulatory networks (GRNs) that oversee proper behavior of biological cells by means of signal transmissions between the genes. GRNs are adaptive to dynamic changes (e.g., noises and perturbations) and also resilient to the removal or malfunction of nodes. Recognizing that WSNs conceptually operate under similar conditions, the BISON project will exploit intrinsic features of GRNs to improve efficiency and robustness of WSNs.

This exploratory project will: (i) establish innovative mapping between GRNs and WSNs by modeling them as graphs, and (ii) apply bio-inspired robust templates in GRNs to design resilient and transmission-efficient WSN topologies. Approaching from biological principles will lead to a novel paradigm shift in robust design of wireless sensor networks with applications in environmental and health monitoring, intrusion detection and target tracking, and vulnerability analysis of cyber-physical systems. The proposed fundamental approach will produce new research in comparing GRN topologies from different organisms under the unifying goal of understanding their information transport robustness.

The BISON project aims to transcend the mapping between biological networks and robust WSNs to other networks such as wireless cellular networks, vehicular and social networks. Research findings will be integrated into existing computer science courses, such as advances in sensor networks and fundamentals of wireless networks, at the Missouri University of Science and Technology, thus training diverse students in an interdisciplinary topic. Efforts will also be made to recruit women and minority students, and engage undergraduates to bio-inspired applications. Research outcomes will be disseminated through a dedicated website, publications and presentations in high quality conferences and journals, and through the Complex Networks Dynamics (CoNeD) workshop co-founded by the PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large-scale wireless sensor networks (WSNs) have recently become more common due to their potential for applications in various domains. Such networks are distributed, heterogonous and dynamic, and often required to operate autonomously without much external control, supporting thousands of nodes. They are also expected to adapt to diverse situations, uncertainties and changing network conditions while functioning robustly in hostile environments, in the wake of failures and attacks. 

In the search for designing robust topology for WSNs, we recognize that many biological or living systems face similar challenges and constraints, such as high degree of autonomy, scalability, adaptability to uncertain conditions. This led to the concept of bio-inspired wireless sensor networks, in which system architectures, networking mechanisms, and communication protocols are designed based on the biological principles. Given that simple living organisms (e.g., Yeast and E-Coli) are comprised of thousands of genes regulating bodily functions, the interactions between the genes have evolved over millions of years and thus become naturally robust. The interactions between the genes can be modeled by Gene Regulatory Networks (GRNs), in which nodes represent the genes and directed edges describe interactions between the genes. GRNs regulate the level of proteins based on the effects that genes have on each other, eventually resulting in modification of the behavior or structure of the organism.

This innovative EAGER project aimed to investigate and understand why GRNs are inherently robust, and how to emulate bio-inspired principles to design highly robust WSNs To this end, the PI contributed significactly by efficiently characterizing GRNs using motifs and embedding of GRNs into WSNs. Mathematical analysis and experimental study demonstrated the efficacy of the proposed approach. Fifteen papers were written and published in high quality journals and conferences, and several invited presentations were made to disseminate the research findings and results. Three Ph.D. students and five undergraduate students were trained through this project. The outcome is better understanding from computational viewpoint why gene regulatory networks in living organisms are robust and how they can help design robust engineering systems like wireless sensor networks.
